messageBody:
I know we have not reached an agreement on how to deal with mergers,
except that each person use the same vowel consistently. This has led to
some funny looking words for me, such as "bomb" appearing <qs>bYm</qs>
Seeing the word spelled with Ah rather than Awl or On made it hard to
recognize. I was so sure it was a mistake in the CMU dictionary, that I
looked it up in my Longman's dictionary, and listed the pronunciation as
Ah. (Longman's merges Ah and On.) Since I don't merge Ah and On like
other Americans, seeing "bomb" spelled this way just seems wrong, "bomb"
is pronounced with a much different vowel than "father."

It occurred to me that I should build my dictionary by not merging Awl,
On, and Ah. If I see "bomb" spelled with "On," I would not be surprised.
If mid-Western American sees "bomb" spelled with On, he would also not
be the least bit surprised. Even if he merges Awl, Oh, and Ah, he will
just recognized On as another way of saying what he recognizes as Ah or
Awl. The letters to him will be interchangeable. On the other hand, if a
British person sees "bomb" spelled with On, he will also not be
surprised, but he would be if it were spelled with "Ah."

So by keeping the Awl Ah On merger separate, I make the news easier to
read for a greater number of people. This seems a short term, workable
solution to one merger. At the same time, I don' think any other mergers
will come into play on the same scale as On-Awl-Ah.

What it means for me is that I will have to look up words like "bomb" in
my Heritage dictionary (which does not merge Ah and On) or at
dictionary.com. At the same time, I could look up the words in a British
dictionary. I can then enter the words in my checked dictionary, and
continue to build this dictionary in a way that will make it more usable
to a larger number of people, rather than having others re-do a lot of
my word.

In his article on spelling reform, Wells makes the following distinction:

"Logically there are two extreme positions one can adopt towards
phonemic contrasts. The maximalist position would say our orthography
must reflect all the contrasts that anyone makes, and the minimalist
position would say we should reflect only those that everyone makes."

I suppose for the purpose of the Ah-Awl-On merger, I am taking somewhat
of a maximalist position. That is, I think it better to have text that
accomodates this distinction, since a great number of English speakers
(though probably not the majority) do make this distinction.

Paul
